page.title: Committee for Peace and Security in the Gulf

rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.

[[Image:Saddam Hussein on his throne.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Saddam Hussein with the [[Flag of Iraq#1991â2004|flag of Iraq]] he implemented during the [[Gulf War]]]]
 
[[Image:WeaponsInspector.JPG|thumb|right|250px|A UN weapons inspector in Iraq.]]
[[Image:WeaponsInspector.JPG|thumb|right|250px|A UN weapons inspector in Iraq.]]
The '''Committee for Peace and Security in the Gulf''' ('''CPSG''') was a "bipartisan group whose members are prominent in U.S. international policy circles.... The 39-member group, organized as the Committee for Peace and Security in the Gulf, include[d] former U.S. Rep. [[Stephen Solarz]] of New York, who was a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee and [[Richard Perle]], a former assistant defense secretary for international security policy." [http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/9802/20/iraq.war.presser] In February 1998, the CPSG asked Clinton "to go beyond a military strike on Iraq and to help overthrow Iraqi President [[Saddam Hussein]] and replace his regime with a provisional government." According to the news report, however, "U.S. law and international opposition to such a plan would make it unlikely."[http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/9802/20/iraq.war.presser/]
The '''Committee for Peace and Security in the Gulf''' ('''CPSG''') was a "bipartisan group whose members are prominent in U.S. international policy circles.... The 39-member group, organized as the Committee for Peace and Security in the Gulf, include[d] former U.S. Rep. [[Stephen Solarz]] of New York, who was a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee and [[Richard Perle]], a former assistant defense secretary for international security policy." [http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/9802/20/iraq.war.presser] In February 1998, the CPSG asked Clinton "to go beyond a military strike on Iraq and to help overthrow Iraqi President [[Saddam Hussein]] and replace his regime with a provisional government." According to the news report, however, "U.S. law and international opposition to such a plan would make it unlikely."[http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/9802/20/iraq.war.presser/]
